Why does it seem the 2012-13 NBA Season has begun ridiculously early? Oh that's right, there was that lockout last year that almost sabotaged the entire season and ensured that games didn't begin until Christmas. This year, the NBA is operating right on schedule, with the regular season beginning Tuesday 30 October. With no labor strife, we have a full slate of basketball goodness ahead.

We've already had a full month of preseason. Everybody has been watching Nate Robinson hitting game-winners and other such deeply meaningful heroics, right? That's way more exciting than things like the MLB playoffs, the NFL and college football...

Okay, maybe this NBA preseason hasn't quite gotten your attention, especially when compared to the entertaining run the USA Men's basketball team pulled off at the London Olympics.

For those who have had better things to do than focus on offseason drama and "imaginary basketball" (as I call the preseason), we present our NBA preview. We'll break down some of the main storylines for each team, a guide to what has happened since the Miami Heat beat the Oklahoma City Thunder in the NBA Finals. For instance, did you know that LeBron James and Kevin Durant are good at basketball? It's true! Where else will you get cutting-edge analysis like that?

(Next up: An in-depth analysis of how the NBA's crackdown on lengthy handshakes will alter the potential playoff landscape.)

Eastern Conference

Atlantic

1 Boston Celtics:

The New Big Three era in Boston is officially over. Ray Allen, upset over being replaced by Avery Bradley (aka "My Guy"), accepted a bench role with the rival Miami Heat despite the fact that the Celtics offered him more money in the offseason. This makes for potentially great drama, especially now that he and his former teammates are already jawing, but it distracts from the very real possibility that this Celtics team could be just as good as they were last year, even if only Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett remain of the championship-winning trio.

That seems a bit strange, of course, considering that they are down a Hall-of-Famer and an already almost ancient team has gotten a full season older, but stick with us. Once Avery Bradley is healthy he could have a good shot at replacing Ray Allen's production. Jeff Green, a year removed from heart surgery, should be nearly as healthy as his new contract. Jason Terry and Courtney Lee should be solid contributors and the absence of the back-to-back games of last year's condensed schedule might allow the older players to save their legs a bit. This was a team that needed just one more win – if against a Heat team featuring LeBron James in Berserker Mode – to advance to the finals.

If the Celtics are one win better it will be because Rajon Rondo has finally taken that next step and become the elite player he has shown flashes of being. It seems every year that the take on the C's is "they need Rondo to step up", but this year it's not just a thing experts say, it's an absolute imperative for an aging team without the best three-point shooter of all time. Rondo is going to need to be a leader, he's going to have to be a more offensive threat and he's going to have to cut down on his on-court mental lapses. With the New Big Three era over, it's officially Rajon Rondo's team and its fortunes rest with him.

2 Philadelphia 76ers

The dust settled on the Dwight Howard Trade, and somehow the Philadelphia 76ers ended up with Andrew Bynum. It sounds like a deal to get one of the last true centers in the game until you realize that they also lost Andre Iguodala in the transaction – he's gone to the Denver Nuggets. The downside to Bynum is that he is injury prone, has a reputation of having motivation problems and is known to make dumb comments. The good news is that Philadelphia fans are known to be incredibly patient with such players.

The 76ers were good enough last year to make it to the Eastern Conference semi-finals, where they played the Celtics in what may have been one of the most plodding seven-game series in modern NBA postseason history. (This is coming from a writer who had rooting interest in the whole thing, mind you.) Are they a better team now, considering they basically swapped Iguodala with Bynum, amnestied Elton Brand and added Kwame Brown? Well they just needed one more postseason win to make it to the Eastern Conference Finals, so the answer is a solid "maybe".

It depends on whether or not Bynum flourishes. He did have the best season of his career last year (including a playoff triple-double over the Nuggets) despite conflicts with Lakers coach Mike Brown and his premature statement that "closeout games are easy". If he remains healthy and keeps his head straight then sure, but does anyone want to take bets on Bynum remaining healthy? If he isn't, Michael Vick will have some company as the biggest target on Philadelphia sports radio.

3 New York Knicks

Status: officially sane again. Yes, Linsanity no longer reigns in New York, as Jeremy Lin has gone to the Houston Rockets – the Knicks management* did not bother to match Houston's offer. Don't worry Knicks fans, New York has made some great signings to make up for the loss of what was the best thing to happen to the franchise in years. For instance, they signed the now-ironically named Jason Kidd and Rasheed Wallace. Hey wait, don't turn your attention to Brooklyn just yet.

We know that doesn't really sound very promising. Don't worry, all it will take for the Knicks to pass the first round of the playoffs for the first time in years is for Carmelo Anthony and Amar'e Stoudemire to learn how to play with each other. That seems simple enough, right? The catch is that the growing consensus is that Stoudemire had more chemistry with the fire extinguisher that broke his hand last postseason than 'Melo. Not that it will matter in the beginning of the year, as Stoudemire will be out with a knee cyst.

More worrisome might be the health of Tyson Chandler, the reigning defensive player of the year (which somehow translates to only second-team defensive all-star in NBA math), who was last seen leaving a preseason game on crutches. If Chandler is healthy, that gives New York a chance: even if Anthony and Stoudemire don't mesh, they're still going to score a bunch of points. As long as they get something out of the point guard position, the Knicks should get into the postseason and might have a chance to take it to the next level. Mind you: that next level might just mean getting bounced in the second round of the playoffs.

* Note: There is a a school of thought that "Knicks management" is, in fact, an oxymoron. Also: Rasheed Wallace, Kwame Brown and Darko Milicic (currently with Boston) are now all in the same division, which is a score for people whose jobs involve making basketball jokes.

4 Brooklyn Nets

Forget Dwight Howard – the biggest trade of the offseason occurred when the New Jersey Nets traded states. Yes, the Nets said goodbye New Jersey and #helloBrooklyn, and that was just the start of their identity change. Owner Mikhail Prokhorov's team bears only a little resemblance to the old New Jersey team. After bowing out of the Dwight Howard sweepstakes by re-signing oft-hurt center Brook Lopez – and aren't they all oft-hurt these days – the Nets decided to build around a resigned Deron Williams and to trade for Joe Johnson and his ridiculous contract. Like that movie in which Ryan Reynolds played Green Lantern, Johnson was ill-suited for the savior role with the Atlanta Hawks. Although vastly overpaid as Williams's sidekick, he still makes the perfect second option for the new-look Nets.

The Nets aren't really worried about money right now – they're more concerned about gaining buzz. On that front, they have not only moved to a hip new location, they even have pop-culture icons! Not only is Jay-Z a part-owner (Okay, he owns like a millionth of the team, but that's something), but the team also features former "Keeping Up With The Kardashians" cast member Kris Humphries. Okay, he's not as popular as Jay-Z – in fact he's the Most Hated Man In the NBA – but there's almost no such thing as bad publicity for a team trying to position itself as the new, big deal in Brooklyn.

Ultimately, the Nets have enough novelty, talent and name recognition to make their debut season a hit as far as getting attention goes. What they don't have is a roster constructed to make them a serious threat to reach the NBA Finals or the cap space to ensure that they will have such a team in the near future. In other words, the Nets are no longer in New Jersey but, well, they're still the Nets.

5 Toronto Raptors

The good news for the Raptors is that they're still the best basketball team in Canada and the best sports franchise whose name was inspired by Jurassic Park. The other good news is that they should be a little bit better this season, especially with the addition of Kyle Lowry, formerly of the Houston Rockets. The young point guard's presence promises that the Raptors will be a more interesting team to watch than you might expect and they could even flirt with the eighth seed in the East, but he's not enough to make locals less depressed about the hockey lockout.

The most Raptors thing in Raptors history happened during this offseason, by the way, when they signed shooting guard Landry Fields to a $20m, three-year deal as part of a complicated gambit to woo point guard Steve Nash. You can't blame the Raptors for wanting to have the best Canadian basketball player ever on their team, but Nash ended up with the Lakers. So now one of their highest-paid players is somebody they didn't even really want. They are almost lovable, these Raptors.

Central

1 Indiana Pacers

The Indiana Pacers had a lot of success last year, but there's some thought that they could come back to Earth. Last season's team, who were something of a surprise, featured such medium names as Danny Granger, Paul George and David West. In fact, the Pacers might be second only to the Oakland A's in baseball as far as contending pro-teams featuring anonymous-sounding players. One big key to their success was Roy Hibbert, who continues to quietly be one of the few true centers left in the game (and the only worthwhile Gangnam Style parodist out there).

With all this success, the one obstacle that could prevent the Pacers from building on last year's success would be their health. To quote Beckley Mason in ESPN: The Magazine (so named as not to be confused with ESPN: The Towel Holder or ESPN: The Gluten-Free Candy Bar): "Paul George, David West, Granger, Darren Collison and Roy Hibbert played 1,000 minutes together – or 253 more than any other NBA teammates spent as a unit". That's a great thing to happen, but it's not something Indiana can realistically expect to happen in back to back seasons.

A nice story for the Pacers might be the addition of Gerald Green, the second-biggest story about a D-League washout becoming a solid contributor. Green didn't have a Jeremy Lin sized impact – who else could – but he proved to be a solid pro-level contributor for the New Jersey Nets and he was responsible for the No1 non-Blake Griffin Dunk of the Year. So, if the Pacers' luck turns and they start suffering a lot more injuries, there's a feelgood story to follow. A feelgood story with dunks.

2 Chicago Bulls

When will Derrick Rose return? Okay, there are other questions to ask about the Chicago Bulls, but that's the key one, isn't it? The other key questions are: When he returns this season (if he returns this season) what will the Bulls be playing for? Will he be anything approximating the Derrick Rose of old? Will he ever be as good as he was before he tore his ACL? For most of the season, Rose will be the post-structuralist critic's dream, the presence notable for its absence.

You know, like Charlie in Charlie's Angels. Except with really cool shoes.

So, assuming that Rose is out for most of the season, and won't fully be himself when he does return, head coach Tom Thibodeau will have an opportunity to live up to his budding reputation as a basketball genius. Luckily, the Bulls are gifted with a few pretty great players, most notably Luol Deng and Joakim Noah. Still, the Bulls are going to be much farther from the championship this year than they were last year before the ACL Injury That Changed Everything. Chicago could have been the team to knock off LeBron James and the Miami Heat? Now, now it's a team whose championship hopes are resting on Rose's uncertain legs.

3 Milwaukee Bucks

The Bucks finally decided that the Andrew Bogut roller coaster had to come to an end, mostly because that ride was always shut down for repairs. So Milwaukee traded their oft-injured center (along with Stephen Jackson) to the Golden State Warriors for the talented but beyond erratic Monta Ellis. Ellis will be a lock to bring a bit of Warriors basketball to the Bucks: lots of offense, little defense and a lot of on-court ridiculousness, both good and bad, that will ensure his name is continually trending on Twitter (albeit misspelled as Monte).

Ellis joins Brandon Jennings as the core of the Bucks, which is a fairly underwhelming duo by any standard. This is probably why the folks at the indispensable basketball blog "Ball Don't Lie" have noted that the Bucks are getting just one nationally televised game this season. That's the kind of television schedule that a .500 team without any name players gets and, well, that's who these Bucks are.

4 Cleveland Cavaliers

On the heels of The Decision, spurned Cleveland Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert wrote a message (in Comic Sans, no less,) that the Cavs would win a title before departed forward LeBron James did. This prediction, to say the least, seems rather unlikely to come to pass without some sort of loophole involving either time travel or the multiple-worlds theory of the universe. The Heat won it all a few months ago, the Cavaliers are still years away from the postseason.

The Cavaliers are again all about one player – this time around it's sophomore guard Kyrie Irving who isn't LeBron but did almost single-handedly revive Cleveland's interest in hoops last season. Kyrie Irving, absolutely the best basketball player to have a Mister Mister song named after him, was an absolute beast last year and if he's able to make a second-year jump the Cavs could be at least a spoiler in the East. The Cavs got some help for Irving, drafting Dion Waiters to be his wingman. Waiters was drafted too high, probably, but the Cavs obviously think that Irving and Waiters will work together well. They won't work well enough to make the Comic Sans Guarantee look any less ridiculous, but well enough to get them knocking on the doors of respectability.

5 Detroit Pistons

It's a good thing the Detroit Tigers are in the World Series, because my stars is Detroit not going to have much fun watching its basketball team this season. Well Okay, big man Greg Monroe's development should be fun to watch, not to mention watching Andre Drummond (who fell to No8 in the draft) play his rookie year. Of course, there's the concert that the Pistons have not committed themselves to playing Drummond significant minutes and would rather play also-rans and never-will-be's instead.

The other thing that Detroit has is that, well... um, this is awkward. There's no way to spin this one, folks: the era of the Detroit Bad Boys is as over as the era of saying "bad as in good". This season, Detroit will just be bad.

Southeast

1 Miami Heat

So, did the Heat do anything interesting last year?

The strangest thing happened to the Heat on their way to their first post-Decision championship: they almost became, if not likable, at least difficult to hate too too much. LeBron James's "inability to come through in the clutch" was dissected to the point where former haters were rooting for him to finally win a ring, just to quiet the Skip Baylesses of the world. Dwyane Wade was clearly playing so injured that it seemed legitimate to speculate that years of playing the game hard were catching up with him for good. Chris Bosh was trying to return, probably too early, from an abdominal injury and dealing with nonstop ridicule that painted him as an effeminate third wheel. Head coach Erik Spoelstra seemed to be just holding a clipboard until the inevitable return of Pat Riley, Mario Chalmers was a Saturday Night Live punchline and the bench was mostly bargain-basement scrubs and completely broken three-point shooters.

Luckily, the Miami Heat are now NBA champions, so we can all go back to hating them. Despite getting some key plays from some of their bench guys during the Finals, most notably when Mike Miller went three-pointer crazy in the season-clinching Game 5, Miami upgraded the bench by bringing in Boston's Ray Allen and New Orleans's Rashard Lewis. Everybody knows their roles now, mainly because the last few months have established that this is very much LeBron James's team.

King James, and we can call him that now, is the reigning regular-season MVP, was the Finals MVP and just got through leading Team USA through the London Olympics. Having won an MVP trophy, a championship ring and a gold medal, James has enough hardware now to open a Home Depot. He's pretty much the best basketball player in the known universe, a dominant force even in the fourth quarters of games and seems as unstoppable as Mike Tyson in the old Nintendo Punch Out game. He is scary good right now, and so is his team.

The question isn't whether or not the Heat are the Goliath of the Eastern Conference. No, the question is whether or not there are any Davids that could prevent them from reaching the Finals for the third straight year. Don't bet on it.

2 Atlanta Hawks

The best news for the Atlanta Hawks is that they got rid of Joe Johnson and his absolutely ridiculous contract, pawning it off on the mad-with-cash Brooklyn Nets. It says something about how finance-savvy modern sports fans are that a perennial playoff team could trade away its best and most high-profile player and that the fan response would be almost universal praise. Or maybe the Joe Johnson contract was just so bad that it was impossible to defend.

Beyond that addition by subtraction, and the wise acquisition of Lou Williams (formerly of the 76ers) as a cheap Johnson replacement, the best thing to happen for the Hawks is that they could get (knock on wood) a full season of a healthy Al Horford. Horford returned to the lineup last postseason and immediately made an impact in their series against the Celtics. The big-man duo of Horford and Josh Smith will make the Hawks a dangerous team during the regular season.

That's the regular season though – could this Atlanta Hawks team get deep in the playoffs? The one thing not in their favor is that they're a pro sports team in Atlanta – just ask Bobby Cox or Matt Ryan how difficult that is in that city. No wonder they exiled first-round elimination magnet Tracy McGrady to China. There's enough bad juju working against them.

3 Washington Wizards

There was a brief spell of happiness in the Washington DC era, a possibility of rebirth highlighted by both Sports Illustrated and ESPN - The Magazine publishing articles focusing on the area. (Okay, SI made them share time with Baltimore, but still.) What happened then? Washington Redskins quarterback Robert Griffin III got injured, the Washington Nationals suffered a 9th-inning collapse in the fifth game of the National League Division Series and, most notably for our purposes, Washington Wizards guard John Wall suffered a knee injury that ensured he wouldn't be returning until November.

Many recent Wizards moves have just been about dumping the malcontent and the mistake-prone (Gilbert Arenas, JaVale McGee, Nick Young), in the hopes of building around the developing Wall. Washington's initial dilemma was figuring out what kind of team can you build around Wall, but that concern has morphed into whether or not Wall is the kind of player you can build around. In any case, Wall's absence gives the Wizards no choice but to play players like Nene, Trevor Ariza and third-round draft pick Bradley Beal and see what else they have. Who knows, maybe some currently unknown player will step up like Jeremy Lin did last year and make fans almost dread Wall's return to the lineup. It's far more likely, however, that Washington fans will do everything short of sacrificing small animals in a desperate attempt to hasten his return.

4 Orlando Magic

Okay, the most important things you need to know about the Orlando Magic are that they no longer have center Dwight Howard and that they're going to be terrible this year and for a very long time to come. In a desperate attempt to keep their star player, his bags already packed, the Magic fired head coach Stan Van Gundy and even made overtures to hire Shaquille O'Neal as GM. These last-minute gestures failed to sway Basketball Hamlet, so the Magic sent him to the Lakers in a trade that also involved the Nuggets and the 76ers.

What was the haul of goodies that the Magic got for trading away the best center in the league? The Magic got Arron Affalo, Al Harrington, Nikola Vucevic, Maurice Harkless, Josh McRoberts, Christian Eyenga and five protected draft picks (three first-rounders and two second-rounders) from the other three teams. What does that mean for Orlando? Who knows. Every other team received proven commodities; the Magic got the basketball talent equivalent of "what's behind door No3". They traded their unhappy franchise player, the center who made their team relevant again, for a handful of... well... magic beans. Somewhere Shaq is laughing, and by somewhere I mean "inexplicably on television still".

5 Charlotte Bobcats

The Charlotte Bobcats had the worst season in NBA history last year, and for their efforts they didn't get even get the first pick in the NBA Draft (ie, they missed out on Anthony Davis). So, chances are that this season has to be a little bit better. Owner Michael Jordan has promised to be less hands-off – I guess his highly competitive nature has realized that a Worst Owner In NBA History award clashed with his status as Greatest Basketball Player Ever.

Well, the Bobcats did get Michael Kidd-Gilchrist with the second pick and they did pick up a veteran free agent in the offseason. Since I don't know what Ben Gordon will provide, I'll say what teams say whenever they pick up older players for no reason. Gordon will provide "veteran leadership". Listen, the Bobcats won't have the worst season in basketball history again. Maybe they will catch a break and won't even be the worst team in the league. Dream big, Charlotte. Dream big.

Prediction:
Eastern Conference Finals: Miami Heat OVER Philadelphia 76ers

I'm not entirely sold on the 76ers but I just don't see the Celtics returning to the conference finals. Philadelphia seems like the team most likely to jump past them. Keep in mind I could have picked the Celtics, the Pacers, the Hawks or a revived, Derrick Rose-led Bulls team here and it would have made no difference. The Heat are going to win the Eastern Conference.

Western Conference

Northwest

1 Oklahoma City Thunder

Their last few games they played didn't turn out as they planned, but the former Seattle Supersonics had their best year ever. The scary part? They could be even better this year. Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook spent their summer playing together on Team USA at the London Olympics. Plus, Serge Ibaka played for Spain and hey, with Dwight Howard in the Western Conference, Kendrick Perkins is now actually useful, considering his history of neutralizing the most dominant center in the game. (Oh yes, this does mean a return of Nick Collison, Undercover Baller.)

My draft summary of the Thunder's offseason discussed whether or not the Thunder could be a potential new dynasty if they managed to keep hold of James Harden. Well that changed on Saturday, after contract extension talks broke down, the Oklahoma City Thunder traded James Harden, their third best player and Sixth Man of the Year to the Houston Rockets. The Thunder sent Harden, along with Cole Aldrich, Daequan Cook and Lazar Hayward, to the Rockets for Kevin Martin, Jeremy Lamb, two first-round draft picks and a second rounder. The Thunder, as any major Trail Blazers fan would tell you, have done well with their draft picks in the past, and considering that Harden was likely to get paid more than he was worth (although not in comparison with, say, a Kendrick Perkins) the payroll flexibility may help them in the long run. Still, it's curious considering that this was a team that was just in the NBA Finals. It could be argued that, for this season at least, the Lakers were a bigger beneficiary of this trade than any of the teams involved

2 Denver Nuggets

The Dwight Howard Trade made the Lakers the favorites to win the West, but it also helped out a team that could be standing in their way. It didn't get as much press, but Andre Iguodala might have more impact on his new team than Howard on his. He's not a Proven Center, that near-mythical beast, like Howard or Andrew Bynum, but Iguodala is a great all-around player, someone who managed to be an underrated Olympic champion. He's the exact right guy to lead a Nuggets team that many experts think is just behind the Thunder and the Lakers in the West.

The Nuggets, and head coach the Venerable George Karl, hope that Iguodala helps out with another one more of their more recent acquisitions, JaVale McGee. Even without Iguodala, the Human Lowlight Reel had an incredible postseason run where he almost single-handedly brought down the Lakers. If the Nuggets can get the most out of the talented seven-footer, meaning less saluting and fewer bone-headed plays, then they might have the core of an amazing team here, even a team that could reach the finals, with a little luck.

3 Utah Jazz

The Utah Jazz, believe it or not, went to the playoffs last year. You can look it up on the internet, although I wouldn't blame you if you wanted to check Snopes first. The Jazz were the last team to get in the playoffs and the first team to get bounced. That result seems believable; the Jazz repeating those results this season also seems believable.

What else is going on for this team? Well, Al Jefferson is an interesting player to watch – he's better than you think he is and he will be a solid rotation player on a major franchise sooner rather than later. The Jazz reacquired Mo Williams, pretty much exactly the platonic ideal of a Jazz player, as well as Randy Foye. It should be another decent season, but keep in mind that "another decent season" is the ceiling for this franchise as currently constituted. Maybe they could try to increase their future playoff chances, or at least public visibility, by finally dumping the Jazz monicker and getting a more appropriate name.

4 Minnesota Timberwolves

The Timberwolves were supposed to be the Most Fun Team In Basketball this year, but instead an injury to Kevin Love has put a damper on their potential postseason success. Love is expected to be gone for six to eight weeks after he broke his hand doing knuckle pushups. No seriously, that's how he broke it.

This wouldn't be such bad news if Minnesota's second best-player, Ricky Rubio, and his reality-bending passing ability, wasn't out with an ACL injury for good portion of the season. Together, they would have made the Timberwolves a serious playoff threat, especially with an improved supporting cast that includes a suddenly unretired Brandon Roy and Andrei Kirilenko. Now, they're just another mediocre Western Conference team.

Oh, they do have Greg Stiemsma now, and Tommy Heinsohn said that he was like Bill Russell. Maybe not all is lost in Minnesota after all what with the... oops, sorry, my Stiemsma paragraph has just fouled out of the preview.

5 Portland Trail Blazers

The Trail Blazers had a good first half of the 2011-12 season before their season collapsed and they basically packed it in around the trade deadline. Don't expect Portland to make a huge jump this year, which seems set to be a water treading one of mere existence. There is maybe a sign or two that the franchise is about to change: the team officially parted ways with oft-broken, near-tragic figure Greg Oden, who not only has played very little but has acted as something of a symbol of Portland's missed opportunities.

Now that the Trail Blazers are officially without Oden, as well as the un-retired Brandon Roy, they can try to find a new identity, theoretically with LaMarcus Aldrirdge at its core. Unfortunately, searching for a new identity makes a really great 1990s independent movie – not a thrilling basketball season.

Pacific

1 Los Angeles Lakers

The Lakers decided to stand pat this offseason, confident that their roster as currently assembled was good enough to challenge for a title. Then they remembered that they were the Lakers and made trades for Dwight Howard and Steve Nash while somehow managing to keep Pau Gasol. It felt like the Lakers won the Western Conference in the offseason.

That's not where championships are won, however. The problem with the Lakers is that they have the kind of team that could collapse at any time. Kobe Bryant, as you may have heard, can be a bit of a ballhog and he's not getting any younger: some nights he's going to look like vintage Kobe and others nights he's going to look more like his dad Jellybean. Second-year head coach Mike Brown's control of the team is also in question. Kobe is basically in charge of the offense; Brown sometimes seems like merely the defensive coordinator. Brown had trouble dealing with the young Andrew Bynum last year, a detail that seems minor now but could be a prelude to trouble with the mercurial Howard. Nash should help team chemistry, that's what the (Formerly) Floppy Haired Canadian does, but his influence will be lessened if his bad back sidelines him. In what may be the most troubling news for team chemistry, Metta World Peace still exists.

The fun part? Dwight Howard is a free agent after the end of this season, which means next year there's a chance that we might go through all of this again with Basketball Hamlet. If there's one surefire motivation, beyond winning a ring of course, for these Lakers to find their chemistry and find it fast, it's to ensure that Howard doesn't have any reason to pull his "to be a Laker or not to be a Laker" stunt.

If the Lakers do all get along, and Howard plays the role of good soldier, they are going to be a very, very difficult team to defeat. This collection of All-Stars is unlikely to last very long, this is as "win now" a team as you could possibly build, but no one in purple and gold will care if they can grab another ring this year. Their biggest enemy may be themselves.

2 Los Angeles Clippers

The Clippers made a few moves that could provide dividends, moves that could help make them a true rival to their Staples Center roommates. With Chauncey Billups out with an Achilles injury, the Clippers have brought in 90s icon and former Sprite pitchman Grant Hill as their Designated Veteran Injury Risk. Also entering the fold? Lamar Odom-Kardashian, back in Hollywood, the only city where he's ever really played to his ability level, after a disastrous Texan exile.

But ultimately? Just like last year, it's going to be all about Lob City, now that point guard Chris Paul and forward Blake Griffin have played a lockout-shortened season's worth of games together, the floor show might just get even more fun to watch. Paul-to-Griffin for the dunk is maybe the most fun combo play by two athletes since Tom Brady to Randy Moss for the touchdown. Assuming you're not on the opposite end of it.

There are two major issues with the Clippers. First of all, Vinny del Negro managed to keep his job as head coach (for now at least). The other issue is a tad longer-term, like Howard with the Lakers, Chris Paul is also free agent after the end of the year. If the Clippers start to lag behind in the West, will Paul want to remain as an afterthought in LA? Will his contract situation loom over the season? If so, that could be a disaster for Clippers owner Donald Sterling, not that many will shed tears for him.

3 Golden State Warriors

Last season, once again, the Golden State Warriors were the most fun bad team in basketball. The Warriors played their heavy-offense/little-defense/erratic-fundamentals game for most of the season, although they were less fun when they traded away the endearingly frustrating Monta Ellis towards the end of the season. In return for Ellis, the Warriors received Andrew Bogut, who may or may not be healed in time for the Mayan Apocalypse, and they still have Stephen Curry likewise. In a best-case scenario health-wise, they will just barely miss the playoffs, but they will miss them in a really fun manner. Like always.

They also have Klay Thompson, who recently was the first-place vote getter in a GM survey about which player was most likely to have a breakout season. I sorta think those dudes know what they're talking about. It's obvious by now that these previews are a tad bit "glass half-full" aren't they?

4 Phoenix Suns

The Suns just missed out on the playoffs last year, losing their spot to the Jazz who were eliminated by the San Antonio Spurs in less time than it took you to read this sentence. Considering that Utah never really had a chance, it would have been better for basketball had there been one last Steven Nash-era Suns/Spurs series, but it just wasn't to be. Nash, as expected, wanted to spend his last few years in the NBA with a contender, so Phoenix worked out a sign-a-trade with the Lakers, sending the Canadian superstar to Los Angeles in exchange for draft picks.

The Suns did acquire Michael Beasley – the former second-round draft pick best known for his marijuana issues – from the Timberwolves, and he might now be the Suns' marquee player. Obviously we're working on a very broad interpretation of the word "marquee", but I suppose somebody had to be. Beyond Beasley and the draft picks, the Suns' other major offsesason acquisition has been Jermaine O'Neal, a walking Walking Dead joke still going two or three years after his career was pronounced legally dead. Looking at this roster, can you really blame Nash for wanting to be on another team, even if that team ended up being the Lakers?

5 Sacramento Kings

Well, they're the Sacramento Kings for now at least. The Kings' owners, the Maloof family, have been having a tug-of-war with the city of Sacramento, alternating between threatening to move the franchise and getting preliminary deals to stay in town for what seems like eternity. It all makes the relationship Dwight Howard had with the Orlando Magic look downright healthy. Be prepared for at least a half-dozen "Kings close to deal to stay in Sacramento" stories, followed by the exact same number of reports that they are heading somewhere else, presumably Anaheim or Seattle.

Even beyond the owners, the Kings are a difficult franchise to root for as they are currently constituted, particularly because their best player, DeMarcus Cousins, continues to be rather immature and there isn't really a support system in place to ensure that he is necessarily going to grow up any time soon. It's the subject of easy jokes that the Maloofs' selling of the naming rights to their stadium has led to it being rebranded as Sleep Train Arena but when was the last time a basketball arena's name ever doubled as a perfect description for the on-court product?

Southwest

1 San Antonio Spurs

It feels like the San Antonio Spurs' playoff run, in which they won 20 straight games starting in the regular season and running through the postseason before the Thunder defeated them in the Western Conference Finals, was their last big hurrah. After all, the Spurs are all a year older now and it seems unlikely that they will get that deep into the playoffs again – certainly that undefeated span seems difficult to duplicate. But do you want to bet against the Spurs?

For the Spurs to have a shot against the Lakers or the Thunder, point guard Tony Parker is going to have to have a repeat of last year's MVP-caliber season. It's strange to think of a Spurs team where Tim Duncan, the ageless wonder, isn't the team's key player, but the younger Parker (in Spurs terms) might be the most important player. Parker, after all, is just back from the London Olympics where he helped lead the French National team, so he's certain capable of taking more of a leadership role.

At the very least, the expanded role of Parker is one of the reason that last year's San Antonio team was... actually fun to watch? Or at the very least not boring. The other reasons would be the other long time Spurs on the team: Manu Ginobili (the Best Sixth Man In NBA History) and Gregg Popovich (Hall of Fame coach). Wait, this season will be interesting? Wow, different times for this franchise right?

2 Memphis Grizzlies

"Basketball blogging nation, I've hit the Memphis Grizzlies.
Help me find some way to talk about this team and please.
What's to say about Zach Randolph or his teammate Marc Gasol?
Will they remain a playoff team or just collapse in the fall?"

Well, no one heeded my call. I guess bloggers don't respond to Chuck Berry parodies like I thought they would. Oh well. The Grizzlies are a solid team, the NBA's oatmeal really, and they should be able to make a playoff run while still being ignored by just about everyone outside Memphis. Marc Gasol, fresh from co-running the silver-medal Spanish team with more famous brother Pau, is one of the more underrated big men in the league. Then, of course, there's Tony Allen to contribute his crazy good defense and his just plain crazy Twitter account. Still, for many basketball fans, they are like that indie movie or cable-TV show that your friends keep telling that you have to watch. The more they hard-sell, the less interested you become.

3 Dallas Mavericks

Before I could even start writing this, reports came in saying that Dirk Nowitzki had gotten injured and would be out for six weeks. That's a pretty brutal loss considering that very few teams' playoff chances revolve around one player as much those of the Mavericks. It didn't have to be like this, as Mark Cuban made no secret in the fact that he wanted in on Dwight Howard and, failing that, the chance to lure Deron Williams away from the Nets – losing out to his Russian counterpart in what I hope ends up being the start of a blood feud.

Even with Nowitzki, this Dallas Mavericks team is full of questions: Does Mark Cuban have some secret plan to push the Mavs into serious contention this season? Will the troubled Delonte West last the season (when he has already been suspended once)? Do any of the once-perennial All-Stars Vince Carter, Elton Brand and Chris Kaman have enough left to add significant value to this team? Will Lamar Odom's defection back to Los Angeles be addition by subtraction? All of these questions will be up in the air. With the exception of the last one, they really should be better without Odom, the Real Househusband.

4 Houston Rockets

For most of the offseason it seemed as if the main story of the Houston Rockets is going to be "Linsanity II" as point guard Jeremy Lin left New York and went south to Texas, where he instantly became the face of the franchise. This may have been less because of Lin's above-average skills at the point and more because he was bringing his name recognition to a team that pretty much lacked everything. The Rockets, who were not expected to contend for anything this year other than avoiding the worst record in the West, seemed more interested in Lin because of the international fanbase they built up during the Yao Ming years than anything else. Still, we've seen Lin perform unexpected miracles on the court. (Lin's famous couch, however, will not be making the trip.)

It seemed as if Lin were going to have to keep the team afloat by himself, but on Saturday the Thunder added James Harden to the mix, which seems like something of a desperation move on Houston's part. James Harden is a great player, a perennial All-Star, but he's not the number one option on a true contender. It seems like the Houston Rockets should be in something close to rebuilding mode, so giving up on some of these draft picks makes very little sense, they likely gave up more for Harden than the Orlando Magic received for superstar center Dwight Howard. Unless this is just one step of a larger process, it's hard not to see the decision to get Harden, like the move to bring in Lin, as at least as much of a marketing strategy as a basketball one. Fear the Linbeardity, Texas..

5 New Orleans Hornets

The last time we were talking about the New Orleans Hornets we were discussing the NBA Draft Conspiracy. After the second Chris Paul trade - the league vetoed the first - the NBA-owned Hornets tumbled far enough down the standings to become a serious lottery team, and to other teams' suspicions, the team owned by the league ended up with the No1 pick in the draft. The Hornets, not being dumb, picked Anthony Davis of the University of Kentucky, who has the most upside of any draft pick since Kevin Durant.

The basketball conspiracy theorists, of which there are many, were suspicious: this could not have been a coincidence. Clearly, David Stern and company were pulling the strings, why else would the lottery itself take place in private if a shadowy cabal didn't want the Hornets to get the first pick of the draft? These conspiracies seem unlikely but if I were a Hornets fan, I would just run with it. It's nice to pretend that the commissioner was in your pocket.

However, the Hornets got the Unibrow and it seems likely that the acquisition will provide immediate dividends. Davis spent his summer vacation playing the role of the Human Victory Cigar for Team USA at London Olympics. In the first few games of the tournament, his first quasi-pro experience, he made some plays late against the "just happy to be there" countries which showed it will at least be fun to watch the kid play.

For good measure, the Hornets snatched up Duke guard Austin Rivers (son of Celtics coach Doc) with the 10th pick. Rivers, with his "shoot first and then shoot again and then ask questions later if there's time" style could just as easily make a huge impact as flame out – either way he's bound to be interesting. Make no mistake, the Hornets are going to play some really bad basketball for a while and this season will all be growing pains, but they won't be terrible for very long. Thank the shadowy cabal, Hornets fans.

Partnerships between major network operators, retailers, and banks have characterised the development of the mobile wallet, and are already becoming integral to the rise in popularity of these services in the UK and Europe.

Just a few weeks ago MasterCard announced a new deal with Everything Everywhere to offer its mobile wallet services exclusively to Orange and T-Mobile customers. Like many service providers, MasterCard believes the move will support the accelerated adoption of payments made with mobile devices thanks to Everything Everywhere's 27 million strong customer base. It's expected that one of the first products to be launched will be an near field communication (NFC)-enabled mobile payments service for those using the Everything Everywhere network.

This is by no means the first partnership of its kind. Project Oscar has now been given the green light by the European Commission, and as such some of the UK's leading mobile operators will be working together to develop a digital wallet. Everything Everywhere, O2 and Vodafone are expected to jointly release a unified smartphone-based service, offering an alternative to cash and credit cards.

This approach to ecommerce will give consumers a joined up shopping experience, allowing them to purchase goods and services using their handsets offline in shops, using contactless technology, as well as online. Standardisation of mobile payments services through industry partnerships is a positive step.

Project Oscar was born out of a desire by a number of mobile operators to create a single platform for mobile payments and mobile marketing systems in the UK, designed to open the door for the joint venture's combined 70.2 million customers to adopt mobile payments and related marketing services en masse.

Currently, the UK is lagging behind in mobile payment adoption compared to other developed and developing nations. The UK's somewhat ageing banking system, which brings with it substantial regulation, is one hindrance. There is also a slow response from banks seeking to develop mobile payments services due to a lack of internal resources – both in terms of budget and personnel.

However, the fact is that a variety of factors need to come together for mobile payments adoption to continue to increase, with standardisation just one important part, and consumer education a second factor.

The London Olympics saw over 3,000 NFC terminals set up around the capital, which will have an impact upon awareness of the benefits of mobile payments for years to come. Barclays has also taken advantage of the fact that Pingit was one of the first mobile payments services to launch in the UK, utilising the technology to make thousands of NFC payments wristbands available to festival goers at this year's Wireless Festival.

Some will, however, question whether there a downside to these exclusive partnerships in the long-term. Through limiting themselves to one audience or customer base, retailers and mobile operators are running the risk of missing out on a potential mass market opportunity. Many are already taking steps to remedy this approach, with O2 launching its O2 Wallet application to both its existing customer base and non-O2 customers.

Similarly, after a short exclusivity period, Barclays Pingit services were made available to customers of all banks. If industry partnerships mean that certain services will not be available to all, the fact is that mass adoption will simply involve a 'survival of the fittest' process, where just one or two major providers will be likely to dominate an industry in which there are currently a large number of companies jostling for space.

If mass adoption was simply down to buy-in from the main industry telecoms providers, retailers and mobile vendors, it would be easy to view the integration of NFC into the iPhone as a future industry turning point. However, the fact that Apple decided not to integrate NFC into its newly launched iPhone 5 highlights the wider developments necessary before mass adoption is a reality in the UK and abroad.

Ultimately, we're still two or three years away from mass adoption of mobile payments, and with so many companies vying for attention in this space it's likely that institutions in effective partnerships will accelerate the roll out of their services.

The development of a mobile payments offering for any major institution is a huge step in the UK and abroad, and Apple clearly realises that this needs to be integrated with existing offerings to maximise its usefulness to the end consumer. While partnerships are important, it's making the service useful and attractive for the consumer that really matters, and it's these developments that will be crucial to the growth of mobile wallet services in the UK.

James Richards is VP of mobile at digital banking provider Intelligent Environments

Stonewall has promised to press ahead with its annual bigot of the year award, despite pressure from two leading banks which have threatened to withdraw sponsorship.

Barclays and Coutts both say they will rethink their support for the British gay charity's annual awards following complaints from Christian campaigners about the singling out of individuals for the bigot category.

High profile figures, including Lord Maginnis and Scotland's Roman Catholic leader, Cardinal Keith O'Brien, have been shortlisted for the award after making insulting and inflammatory comments about homosexuality or gay marriage.

"Coutts are sponsors only of Stonewall's writer of the year award and have in no way been involved in the judging or support of the bigot of the year category," the bank said. "We have advised Stonewall that we will be withdrawing our support of the awards unless they remove this category."

Mark McLane, the managing director and head of global diversity and inclusion at Barclays, said his company did not support the bigot category "either financially or in principle and have informed Stonewall that should they decide to continue with this category we will not support this event in the future. To label any individual so subjectively and pejoratively runs contrary to our view on fair treatment, and detracts from what should be a wholly positively focused event."

Ben Summerskill, Stonewall's chief executive, said the charity had no intention of amending or dropping the category. "We have never called anyone a bigot just because they disagreed with us," he said. "All the nominees have gone well beyond what anyone normal would call a decent level of public discourse. We welcome sponsorship from anyone who shares our core values, but we have an obligation to the 3.6 million gay people to do what is right, and highlighting extreme examples of bigotry when we know how harmful this unpleasantness is to the self-esteem of young people is right."

Five figures were shortlisted: Simon Lokodo, the Ugandan ethics and integrity minister, who disbanded meetings of gay equality groups and arrested activists; Maginnis, who described same-sex marriage as "unnatural and deviant behaviour"; O'Brien, who attacked same-sex relationships as "harmful to the physical, mental and spiritual wellbeing" and compared them to slavery; Philip Tartaglia, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Glasgow, who said the late David Cairns MP may have died because he was gay and claimed the death was shrouded in a "conspiracy of silence"; and Alan Craig, the Christian campaigner and former leader of the Christian People's Alliance, who compared gay equality advocates to the invading forces of Nazi Germany, dubbing them the "Gaystapo".

The bigot prize is one of three, with shortlists formed from votes by Stonewall supporters, the others being for community group and hero of the year. It is funded by individual donations.

Among those nominated for the hero award is the Anglican churchman and Guardian columnist the Rev Giles Fraser. The event, to be held at the Victoria & Albert Museum on Thursday, will be hosted by the TV presenter Gok Wan.

Andrea Minichiello Williams, the chief executive of Christian Concern, applauded the stance taken by Barclays and Coutts. "In seeking to humiliate and intimidate those who hold mainstream views on marriage rather than engaging with their arguments, Stonewall is stifling robust public discussion of an issue of great importance to the future of our society," she said.

"It is deeply ironic that an organisation that claims to be opposed to bullying and even runs an initiative in primary schools entitled Celebrating Difference responds to difference of opinion by resorting to name-calling that, were it not more sinister, would be reminiscent of playground antics."

Last year's winner of the bigot award was the Daily Mail writer Melanie Phillips. In 2010 it was the now justice secretary Chris Grayling, after he was secretly recorded upholding the right of bed and breakfast owners to bar gay couples. Last month, the 2012 nominee Craig said if he won and was invited, he would be willing to collect his prize in person.

There are two four-letter words that sum up today's announcement that Hitachi is buying the Horizon nuclear power business abandoned by German-owned RWE and E.on after the Fukushima disaster led Angela Merkel to turn her back on building new reactors. The first is "phew", the overwhelming sentiment from ministers and from Horizon's former owners.

For ministers, the big hole in their low-carbon energy plans that would be left by a failure to get new nuclear plants built is now less likely, For RWE and E.on, they have offloaded the nuclear sites for a lot more cash - £700m - than they might have expected. The fact that even EDF, a supposed competitor to Horizon, "welcomed" Hitachi's purchase shows how close to meltdown the plan to build new nuclear plants has come.

The second four-letter word, from those who oppose new nuclear power in the UK, is unprintable. Hitachi's purchase is undoubtedly a blow for them. But despite the government's delight – Prime minister David Cameron was rolled out to herald the news – today's development is a small step on a long road.

The second energy announcement today, the shortlisting of four carbon capture and storage projects in the government's £1bn competition, could be the more significant news. It now looks likely that contracts for one or two CCS demonstrations will be signed within a year. That's very welcome given the government's current emphasis on gas, because that means CCS is going to be needed.

But the prospect of new reactors at Horizon's sites at Wylfa on Anglesey and Oldbury in Gloucestershire remains much more distant. Cameron said: "This is a decades-long, multi-billion pound vote of confidence in the UK," But what Hitachi has bought, whatever it says about "a 100 year commitment", is an option, nothing more. For its £700m, it now has sites with permission build two or three reactors on each. That is lot of money, but its probably less than 1% of the total value of running six reactors for 60 years.

Before it does so, it needs to get its nuclear technology licensed in the UK: that can take years. Next, it has to finance tens of billions of pounds of investment to build the new plants. That will of course depend on what price the government decides to guarantee for electricity from new nuclear power.

French state-controlled EDF is leading that crucial negotiation, which is the subject of intense speculation. The best guess for what EDF is demanding is high - probably between £100 and £140 per MWh, comparable to offshore wind. The question is whether ministers are prepared to commit energy customers to paying that for decades. It is notable that, despite half a century of taxpayer subsidies, the cost of nuclear energy is rising, while the cost of energy from the much younger renewable sector is falling.

But do not underestimate the government's attachment to the nuclear project. You'd be forgiven for thinking the energy ministry had been entirely captured by the nuclear industry with, as I reported a year ago, several EDF staff working on secondment in government and civil servants returning the favour by working for the energy companies, including Horizon.

There was more today, with the announcement of a new Nuclear Industry Council. The Nuclear Industry Association's chairman John Hutton said: "The new council symbolises the long-term strategic partnership developing between the UK nuclear industry and the government." It certainly does. There is no Renewable Industry Council or any renewable energy industry staff on secondment in the department for energy and climate change (Decc).

The CCS news is thankfully more straightforward, and allows the five-year fiasco of the previous CCS competition to be buried. In many scenarios CCS is crucial to meeting future carbon targets and even more so should new nuclear falter. Minister's shortlisted the four projects in seven months and those chosen wisely span the range of CCS technology. Only one is on a gas plant, with the other three on coal power stations. That is unfortunate, given the government's current "dash for gas", says Prof Stuart Haszeldine, a CCS expert at University of Edinburgh, but results from a historical focus in coal.

One surprise was the failure of 2Co Energy's Don Valley CCS project to wind government support, given that it was seen to be the most advanced and most favoured by the EU for potential matched funding. But Haszeldine said there were "sensible" reasons for the decision, including the lack of permission for a 50km onshore pipeline.

The coalition is committed to supporting four commercial-scale CCS projects, but this competition won't support more than two. Haszeldine says splitting the £1bn pledged by government between a pair of projects "would just about work". He adds: "There is now a six-week period to do the commercial bit. It's about Decc knocking heads together to see if the companies can improve the commercial terms of the deals by co-operating" on, for example, shared pipelines.

In a decade or two's time, I wonder which of today's two announcements - nuclear and CCS - will have been more significant: a renaissance for an old industry or the flowering of a new one.

On Cocody University campus, the biggest in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, workers are busy – finishing paint jobs, planting shrubs and installing tables and chairs for around 62,000 students (out of 85,000 in the whole country). The university is reopening after 18 months. All three Ivorian universities closed in April 2011, following "les évènements", as they euphemistically call the civil war between supporters of former president Laurent Gbagbo's Ivorian People's Front and those who backed the current president, Alassane Ouattara. Around 3,000 people were killed during the conflict.

In the last decade, the Student Federation of Ivory Coast (Fesci) gradually took over the Cocody campus, and it was the scene of violent clashes during the civil war. The "student union" had become a pro-Gbagbo militia led by fake students, and it imposed a reign of terror based on racketeering, rape and murder. "During the repairs a mass grave was discovered on the campus," says Cissé Ibrahima Bacongo, the higher education and research minister.

After being vandalised and stripped bare, nothing remained of the buildings but their outer shell. All the computers, files, records and books had vanished. "As if they had wanted to make it impossible for the students to return," the minister recalls. Before the repairs could begin, the authorities had to evacuate several thousand squatters who settled in the wreckage of the buildings.

Rebuilding the universities and making the start of the new school year a success thus became a key political issue for the government. To finish the repairs in record time, the ministry turned to local building contractors and authorised them to take out loans to cover the initial funding of work, worth about $220m – three times the original estimate.

"It's true that we overlooked the cost of laying new turf, repairing the roads and laying optic fibre," Bacongo admits. But the budget overrun is so large that Ouattara has ordered an inquiry into the tendering process.

In just a few months there has been a radical change. Visiting the campus in September, the French ambassador, Georges Serre, said: "I am bowled over by the speed and quality of the work carried out." The campus now boasts 140 buildings – libraries, brand new lecture theatres, student residences and sports facilities – spread over a 200-hectare landscaped park and connected by a fibre-optic network. On 3 September, at the official re-opening ceremony, the education minister presented the keys of the country's three main universities to their newly appointed presidents.

Cocody has been renamed after Félix Houphouët-Boigny, the country's first president after independence. Abobo-Adjamé, also in Abidjan and originally the science faculty, has become a separate establishment under a new name, Nangui-Abrogoua, after the warrior who founded the former capital in the 18th century. Last, Bouaké has become Alassane Ouattara University, in honour of the president.

It is an administrative challenge to enrol – or re-enrol – students when all the records have been lost. In addition, there are three years' worth of school-leavers, who have been deprived of higher education since June 2010 and must now be accommodated in the first-year intake.

"We asked members of the administrative staff to bring back any handwritten records they might have kept, so that they could be scanned with help from the Association of French-speaking Universities," says Yao Tano, president of Nangui-Abrogoua University. New teaching staff had to be recruited too, including 100 or so for Houphouët-Boigny and another 30 at Nangui-Abrogoua, drawing on the Ivorian diaspora in an attempt to bring graduates home from abroad, particularly from France.

The students whom Le Monde met at the end of September were doubtful about classes actually starting as planned. Computers and lab equipment still hadn't arrived. They were also worried about the increase in fees, up from around $12 to $200 for a bachelor's degree – with the state covering two-thirds of the cost this year. About 30 students have already started their course at Abidjan Ecole Normale Supérieure. "It is urgent to consolidate secondary education, which has suffered recently, as you can see from the poor 17% success rate for the baccalaureate exam this year," says Valy Sidibé, the school's head.

The government has seized the opportunity to reorganise higher education to bring it into line with international standards, in particular the three-tier degree system. Admissions will be restricted to suit the real capacity of specific courses, but selection criteria have yet to be decided. "We will only allow students to repeat a year once," says Bacongo, who is determined to oust "professional" students, thought to number between 2,000 and 5,000, including Fesci troublemakers. The government also plans to launch three new universities in other areas of the country.

I was fascinated by Hanna Rosin's article, Men: an endangered species? (19 October). Rosin perceptively catalogued the changing roles of men and women both in the economy and in the home. But what I missed was any consideration of the effect that these changes have on children: the one group in our society that is voiceless and invisible. From the womb onwards it is the voices of men and women that we hear, not the voices of the children.

The facts were spelled out by President Obama himself, a man who grew up without a father. In a speech on Father's Day 2008, he said: "Children who grow up without a father are five times more likely to live in poverty and commit crime; nine times more likely to drop out of school and 20 times more likely to end up in prison." Fatherlessness is a serious problem in the newly emerging society so expertly mapped by Rosin. And for many children, actual fatherlessness is compounded by functional motherlessness as children are shuttled from bed to the childminder to school, back to childminder and back to bed.

I am not arguing for the hopeless policy of putting the clock back, but for a more complete understanding of the roles of men and women that includes the needs and rights, not only of the adults, but of the people least able to make their voices heard, their children.
Martin Down
Witney, UK

• What is Hanna Rosin saying? A number of things: a) women are making progress in all fields; b) men have difficulty coping with the change; c) in general, this is good. She is generally right – especially about the last. We certainly need more women in top places – both in politics and in the economy.

But why are women so adaptable and men so inflexible? Rosin says that the nature v nurture question on this is unanswerable, but it is clear she is leaning towards the latter explanation.

Alas, it turns out that although she mentions evolutionary psychology her view of it is rather simplistic. Evolutionary psychology points to the interaction between genes and the environment. There is a spectrum of traits and behaviours – from ones that are almost exclusively determined by genes to ones almost exclusively determined by society.

Violence is one of the former. Rosin says that women are becoming more aggressive and even violent. Are they? Are we to assume they are going to overtake men at some point – as they have in the field of academic success? I do not think so.

Mate preferences fall somewhere in between. Rosin says that there is an international market for spouses, with men looking for women with more traditional views. I would like to argue that the main reason behind this market is different: men use their higher status to find younger women from poorer countries.

And what about women? Why is there no similar market for men – with the modern, successful women looking for different men? Could it be that despite their success, women are still looking for someone swooping in on a white horse?

Rosin's last point that there is no "natural order", only the way things are, is the perfect expression of the moralistic fallacy. It suggests that things can change in any direction we would like – without constraints.

Yet as the great EO Wilson once said, "nature holds us on a leash". There may be no natural order but there are natural predispositions. Would it not be great if culture and socialisation could rid us of our sweet tooth? Think about this next time you walk past an ice-cream shop.
Nick Michelioudakis
Athens, Greece

Cuban missile crisis

I was disappointed to read Richard Gott's article on the Cuban missile crisis (How Cuba won the missile crisis, 19 October), even though I agreed with everything he wrote. The problem was what he left out, which concerns US activities the previous year. The standard US account blames the Russians for an act of aggression when they began to install missile bases in Cuba in 1962. Kennedy is then presented as a heroic statesman who takes the world to the brink of nuclear disaster, but manages to avert a third world war by sheer determination.

What the US account conveniently omits is the installation of US missile bases in Turkey and Italy the previous year. The Russians had protested about those installations – which are roughly the same distance as that from Cuba to the US. They described it as an act of aggression because it destabilised the balance of power between the two military systems. The US ignored those protests and went ahead. Seen in that context, the Cuban missile crisis was caused by the US, not by Russia.

Luckily for all of us, reason won through and the crisis was resolved. The US achieved a propaganda victory and was able to peddle its distorted account of events. Anyone writing about those events should make sure to provide the proper context, to avoid perpetuating a misleading account.

Edinburgh, UK

Hard burden of proof

The Jimmy Savile case has highlighted how the odds are stacked against victims. Jonathan Freedland describes "the curious protection granted to so many rapists: the refusal to believe the victims" (This evil is not just one man's, 19 October).

Not only is this the case, but legally the burden of the proof is on the victim. Rape, like any crime, has to be proven "beyond reasonable doubt", failing which the accused is to be considered innocent. But what exactly does this mean?

That hard evidence is required? Or that the victim's side of the story is more plausible than that of the accused? DNA testing is far from systematic; surveillance cameras are usually not available.

Having served recently on jury service without much guidance as to how to interpret "beyond reasonable doubt", several jurors were unwilling to return a guilty verdict in the absence of hard proof. For any rape that takes place without witnesses the legal system makes it extremely difficult to reach a verdict of guilty.
Maroussia Rochigneux
Bristol, UK

Pakistan: it's complicated

It is disappointing to find in the article about Malala Yousafzai, shot by the Taliban in Swat valley (Anger as Taliban shoot girl who spoke out, 19 October), a lack of understanding of the political forces that shape the interlinked conflicts in Pakistan. The article refers to a solidarity rally in Karachi that 40,000 people attended. The solidarity rally was less about Malala Yousafzai and more about the conflict in Karachi.

This is a significant misrepresentation of events.
